{{Infobox NCAA football school | CurrentSeason = | TeamName = Cal State Fullerton Titans football | Image = CSUFtitans.jpg | ImageSize = | HeadCoachDisplay = Gene Murphy (final Titans head coach) | HeadCoachLink = Gene Murphy | HeadCoachYear = 13 | HCWins = 59 | HCLosses = 89 | HCTies = 1 | Stadium = Titan Stadium (Cal State Fullerton) | StadCapacity = 10,000 | StadSurface = Grass | Location = Fullerton, California | ConferenceDisplay= Big West | ConferenceLink = Big West Conference | ConfDivision = | FirstYear = 1970 | LastYear = 1992 | AthlDirectorDisp = | AthlDirectorLink = | WebsiteName = | WebsiteURL = | ATWins = 107 | ATLosses = 150 | ATTies = 3 | ATPercentage = .417 | BowlWins = 0 | BowlLosses = 1 | BowlTies = 0 | AllAmericans = | Color1 = Blue | Color1Hex = 003473 | Color2 = Orange | Color2Hex = FF6600 | FightSong = | MascotDisplay = | MascotLink = | MarchingBand = }}
The '''Cal State Fullerton Titans [[College football|football]] team''' represented [[California State University, Fullerton]] from the [[1970 college football season|1970]] through [[1992 NCAA Division I-A football season|1992 seasons]]. The Titans originally competed as a member of the [[California Collegiate Athletic Association]] from 1970-1973 before moving to the [[Pacific Coast Athletic Association]] (now the Big West) in 1974 where they remained through the [[1991 NCAA Division I-A football season|1991 season]]. The Titans would compete in their final year as an [[NCAA Division I-FBS independent schools|I-A Independent]] prior to the program being disbanded. Fullerton played its home games at multiple stadiums throughout their history with the most recent being [[Titan Stadium (Cal State Fullerton)|Titan Stadium]], in [[Fullerton, California|Fullerton]], [[California]].
==History== The Cal State Fullerton football team traces its roots to [[1969]] when in May, former [[USC Trojans football|USC]] assistant coach [[Dick Coury]] was hired as the program's first head coach.<ref name="December 8, 1992">{{cite news | last =Carr | first =Janis | title =CS Fullerton drops football - Program scheduled for reinstatement in 1994 at lower level, smaller budget | work =The Orange County Register | date =December 8, 1992}}</ref> The team would win their inaugural game against [[California State Polytechnic University, Pomona|Cal Poly Pomona]] by a score of 31–0 on September 19, 1970, and play to a 0–0 tie in their inaugural home game against [[California Lutheran University|Cal Lutheran]] at [[Anaheim Stadium]].<ref name="December 8, 1992"/> Following moderate success in the inaugural 1970 season with a record of 6–4–1, the 1971 season was marked with tragedy when a plane crash on November 13, 1971, resulted in the deaths of three Titan assistant coaches: Joe O'Hara, Dallas Moon and Bill Hannah. Just two weeks following the incident, Fullerton played before their largest ever home crowd of 60,415 at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]] against the [[Grambling State Tigers|Grambling State University Tigers]].<ref name="December 8, 1992"/>
Entering the 1972 season, the Titans would move their home games from Anaheim Stadium to the [[Santa Ana Bowl]], with [[Pete Yoder]] starting the season as the program's second all-time head coach. After completing a pair of 7–4 seasons, the Titans would suffer their first losing season following a 4–7 campaign in the 1974 season.<ref name="December 8, 1992"/> It was during this year that Fullerton would make the move from the [[California Collegiate Athletic Association]] into the [[Pacific Coast Athletic Association]] (now the Big West).<ref name="December 8, 1992"/>
For the 1975 season, Fullerton would hire former [[University of the Pacific (United States)|Pacific]] assistant coach [[Jim Colletto]], as the third head coach in program history. During the Colletto era, the Titans would not have a winning season, with the lone bright spot of his tenure coming in 1978 with [[Obie Graves]] rushing for 1,789 total yards including 291-yards in a 34–9 upset of [[Long Beach State]].<ref name="December 8, 1992"/> Colletto would be removed from his position following the 1979 season with [[Gene Murphy]] being announced as the program's fourth all-time head coach on December 16, 1979.<ref name="December 8, 1992"/>
Entering Murphy's first season, the Titans would move their home games to a temporary on-campus stadium, and continue to not see success on the field with losing seasons from the 1980 through the 1982 seasons.<ref name="records"/> For the 1983 season, Fullerton would again move their home games, this time to [[Cerritos College]] in addition to making the 1983 [[California Bowl]] after winning their first conference championship.<ref name="December 8, 1992"/> The Titans would build upon the successes in finishing the 1984 season again as conference champion with a record of 11–1. Following the season, Murphy was named UPI West Coast Coach of the Year and the Titans would finish in the final top 20 UPI poll.<ref name="December 8, 1992"/> The Titans would never again reach the highs of the 1984 season and would embark on a steady decline through the late 1980s and into the early 1990s.<ref name="records"/>
By the late 1980s, the program was in financial trouble with the Fullerton Academic Senate voting 24–7 to recommend disbanding the program. Although halted by then-university president Milton A. Gordon, on December 7, 1992, Fullerton announced that it would suspend the program effective immediately for a year, with the intention of returning to play at the [[Division I-AA]] level for the 1994 season.<ref name="December 8, 1992"/> However the move to I-AA never occurred and Fullerton has been without football since 1992.
By 1995, the notion of resurrecting the program began to take shape. In fall 1995, the Fullerton Students Athletic Advisory Committee asked the student body in an election if they supported Titan football. At that time, 89 percent of respondents voted favorably for the reinstatement of football.<ref name="November 16, 1995">{{cite news | last =Carr | first =Janis | title =Movement to resurrect Titans football gaining steam | work =The Orange County Register | date =November 16, 1995}}</ref> The effort to resurrect the program continues to this day,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bringbacktitanfootball.com/|title=Bring Back Titan Football}}</ref> complete with a petition<ref name="petition">{{cite web|url=http://www.tailgatingideas.com/2007/11/09/bring-back-titan-football/|title=Petition To Reinstate Cal State Fullerton Titan Football|accessdate=2008-12-10|publisher=TailgatingIdeas.com}}</ref> to reinstate the football team.
Although the Titans have not played a game since 1992, Fullerton is still the NCAA record holder in several categories. These records include: both most fumbles and most fumbles lost for a single season with 73 and 41 respectively during the 1992 season;<ref name="NCAARecords">[http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/football_records/DI/2008/FBS%20compiled.pdf Fumbles] "Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) Records," NCAA, July 2008. p. 27. Accessed 2008-12-11</ref> the most kickoff returns per game with an average of 7.3 per game for the 1990 season;<ref name="NCAARecords2">[http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/football_records/DI/2008/FBS%20compiled.pdf Kickoff Returns] "Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) Records," NCAA, July 2008. p. 27. Accessed 2008-12-11</ref> the 10th highest number of rushing yards in a single game with 357 by Mike Pringle on November 4, 1989, against New Mexico State;<ref name="NCAARecords3">[http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/football_records/DI/2008/FBS%20compiled.pdf Rushing - Single Game Yards] "Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) Records," NCAA, July 2008. p. 34. Accessed 2008-12-11</ref> and being part of the fourth highest combined score in a tied game with their 41–41 contest against [[San Diego State Aztecs football|San Diego State]] on September 23, 1989.<ref name="NCAARecords4">[http://web1.ncaa.org/web_files/stats/football_records/DI/2008/FBS%20compiled.pdf Highest-Scoring Tie Games] "Football Bowl Subdivision (FBS) Records," NCAA, July 2008. p. 128. Accessed 2008-12-11</ref>

==Titans in the Pros== ===In the NFL=== California State University, Fullerton has 22 alumni that have played in the [[National Football League]].<ref name="nfltech">{{cite web|url=http://www.databasefootball.com/players/bycollege.htm?sch=California+State+University%2C+Fullerton|title=NFL Players who attended California State University, Fullerton|publisher=databasefootball.com|accessdate=2008-12-10}}</ref> {| cellpadding="1" border="1" cellspacing="0" width="60%" text-align:"center" !bgcolor="#003473"|<font color="FF6600">Name !bgcolor="#003473"|<font color="FF6600">Position !bgcolor="#003473"|<font color="FF6600">Year !bgcolor="#003473"|<font color="FF6600">Overall Pick !bgcolor="#003473"|<font color="FF6600">Team |-align="center" style="background: #ffffff;" | Mike Ernst || QB || 1972 || Free Agent || [[Denver Broncos]] |-align="center" style="background: #ffffff;" | [[Johnnie Gray]] || S || 1975 || Free Agent || [[Green Bay Packers]] |-align="center" style="background: #ffffff;" | M. L. ===In the CFL=== In addition to the players that competed in the NFL, there have been several former Titans that have had significant careers in the [[Canadian Football League]]. The three players of note include: [[Mike Pringle (football)|Mike Pringle]] who is the league's all-time leading rusher,<ref name="Pringle">{{cite web|url=http://www.cfl.ca/page/stats_indrec_rushing|title=Regular Season All-Time Records: Individual Records -Rushing|accessdate=2008-12-10|publisher=CFL.ca}}</ref> [[Damon Allen]], the league's all-time leading passer and former [[List of gridiron football quarterbacks passing statistics|all-time pro football passing leader]] with 72,381 passing yards,<ref name="Allen">{{cite web|url=http://www.cfl.ca/page/stats_indrec_passing|title=Regular Season All-Time Records: Individual Records - Passing|accessdate=2008-12-10|publisher=CFL.ca}}</ref> and [[Allen Pitts]], the league's all-time leading receiver until 2008 when he was surpassed by [[Milt Stegall]].<ref name="Pitts">{{cite web|url=http://www.cfl.ca/page/stats_indrec_receiving|title=Regular Season All-Time Records: Individual Records - Receiving|accessdate=2008-12-10|publisher=CFL.ca}}</ref>
